Not Vulture, not Michael Keaton. His backstory is captivating and even emotional, we learn the struggles he's been through life and how hard he wants to protect it. The first 15 to 20 minutes of the movie's runtime are dedicated to the villain, which is a pretty uncommon method to follow, but it works brilliantly. Keaton delivers as expected and elevates his character even more with his amazing performance.

The script is great, it is smart and extremely hilarious. It also focused more on telling a Peter Parker story as a teenager instead of just expanding the MCU by throwing some badass Spider-Man action scenes and this is what Marvel struggled at the beginning with the origin stories of its heroes, but it has been pretty much solved since the first Avengers film.

There's a great twist in the transition to the third act that transforms it into a much deeper and emotional final standoff between our superhero and the villain. Also, there are two post- credits scenes, so make sure you stick to the end.

So, what bogged the movie down for me? There are a lot of tones throughout the film: there's comedy, then action, then drama, then romance ... The balance of it all isn't as smooth and fluid as it should be, which affected the movie's pacing (during the second act, it briefly becomes a little boring).

However, my main issue with the film are the under-developed secondary characters. Besides Ned Leeds (Jacob Batalon), who actually gets a lot of screen time, the rest of the cast are basically either stereotypical teenagers or plot devices. I know that they're not the key to a great movie neither the big focus of attention, but when they're so connected to the superhero's personality and daily routine, I think they should have been way more explored (especially when one of the characters is directly linked to the big twist).

One way to solve the previous problem would be to balance the action scenes with those needed character-development moments. The action is mostly fine, but that's it. It's fine, it's not bad, but it's not great. It is entertaining, it is visually appealing and it has its beautiful comic moments, but it's far from being awesome (for example, I don't have the need to go on to Youtube and search for THAT amazing unforgettable scene because there isn't one ... ).

All in all, Spider-Man: Homecoming delivers a very entertaining reboot of the series and it fits perfectly into the MCU. Tom Holland is the best on-screen Spider-Man ever, Michael Keaton is brilliant as the fully-developed Vulture and the script is super smart and extremely funny. A few tone balancing issues affect the film's pacing, the side characters are under-developed and the action didn't wow me, but it didn't change the fact that I loved this movie.

  • MSB Reviews - If you like my reviews, please follow my blog :)

title: Good but flawed
review: It is well made and shot! All the action scenes were gripping, especially the elevator scene. I like how Peter Parker is portrayed as an excited, bubbly dorkish character but I remember he's a total genius too (which he isn't in the movie?). Great side character choices though. The major hole in the movie (and what I had been really looking forward to watching) is his origin story. How he was bitten, how he adjusted to his powers, etc. People might say they've seen that already, and I understand their point of view, but for me, the way he became Spiderman is the most important part of his story. Also, he's more dependent on gadgets? His suit was damn cool! I totally enjoyed his mishaps with his suit and I would love to see more of it too. But I was expecting something that would give him that edge...traits and powers that are unique to Spiderman. His body was changed by a spider bite but he got only super-strength and that's kinda plain. Other than that, it's a fun watch.

title: A fun one timer popcorn event with more Spider-Man magic
review:
A more immature version of the famous superhero, that is an enjoyable ride of self-discovery, adulthood and classic "save the day" action. The film takes several small and teeny steps, one at a time to develop the plot -- but it ultimately works as a standard story of great, but meager originality to its main premise. Twists and fun action are big pluses, but fragments of anticlimactic humor and poor character development are forcefully pushing the film down. But in the end it still serves as a fun one timer popcorn event, and that successfully restores the magic to the character that 'The Amazing Spiderman'- franchise totally ruined.

Personal rating: 70/100 Critical rating: 70/100

title: Spider-Man finally (kinda) comes home to Marvel Studios... and oh, is it glorious.
review:
Welcome home Spider-Man, we missed ya.

Alright, I have to be transparent here, I'm completely biased on this one. I grew up with this character; from the 2002 classic Spider-Man, to the 2004 classic Spider-Man 2, to the 2007 not-so-classic Spider- Man 3. I genuinely love all three of the original Sam Raimi directed films.

When the two Marc Webb directed films The Amazing Spider-Man and The Amazing Spider-Man 2 were released in 2012 and 2014 respectively, I did a bit of brain gymnastics to convince myself that these movies were just as great as the original trilogy. Eventually, I came to the conclusion that the two Marc Webb films do not compare (specifically The Amazing Spider-Man 2; that film is a mess).

All this to say that maybe I love this character too much to be objective.

But even from an objective viewpoint, this film is outstanding. Spider Man: Homecoming has the difficult task of rebooting the iconic franchise once again. Everyone knows Peter Parker was bitten by a spider, everyone knows Peter Parker's parents are dead, and everyone knows Uncle Ben was murdered. Thankfully, Homecoming wastes no time dwelling on aspects that were explained in the last 5 films. Instead, we get to focus on a story of a childish, inexperienced Spider-Man that truly does not know what he is doing.

Tom Holland is excellent in and out of the Spidey suit, and it isn't too much of a stretch to say this is the most accurate on-screen adaption of Peter Parker. Holland has the infectious energy of an excited child throughout, something that is missing in all the other Spider-Man films.

This is a packed cast, and everyone here delivers, specifically Michael Keaton as Vulture, who surprisingly might be one of the best MCU villains to date. This is a character that could have easily been a throwaway that just came off as corny, but Keaton's acting ability definitely adds a lot to this role.

One of the best additions to this film is Robert Downey Jr, who comes in and out of the film as Iron Man. Jaded veteran Tony Stark's acts as a perfect foil and mentor to the innocent amateur in Peter Parker. The contrast between these two result in some hilarious scenes, as well as some sincere father-son moments. 

With five standalone Spider-Man movies preceding Homecoming, originality is going to be hard to come by; especially when it comes to the action scenes. Thankfully, the action set pieces here are diverse and set a original, entertaining stage for Spider-Man to shine. From the Washington monument in D.C, to a ferry in Staten Island, to the bottom of a plane, all of the action scenes feel extremely fresh.

Where Homecoming really shines is it's comedy. This is the funniest film I've seen all year, even including "comedy" films (I'm looking at you, The House). This is a great example of how you make comedy organic in an action film (I'm looking at you, Transformers). Nearly every actor in the film has some comedic dialogue to deliver on, and nearly every joke hits. A standout here is Zendaya, who is hilarious in every scene she's in. Even singer/actor/rapper/comedian/??? Donald Glover makes a brief but hilarious appearance halfway through the film.

Some might not like the more lighthearted approach to Spider-Man, as this is definitely more cheerful than any of the Sam Raimi or Marc Webb films. But if you were looking for a ultra-serious superhero story why would you watch a Spider-Man film?

Director Jon Watts, this entire cast, and every single one of the 8 credited screenwriters should be commended here as they deliver an original take on a familiar franchise. Spider-Man: Homecoming is easily one of the best films to come out this year, and you should go see this on the biggest screen possible.

title: "Spider-Man: Homecoming"- Welcome home, Spidey! A fabulous return for one of the most beloved and iconic comic-book heroes ever created!
review:
Over the past nine years, as Marvel's Cinematic Universe has risen to legendary status in the world of entertainment, there has always been one consistent and never-ending hope in the minds of fans the world over... that perhaps one day, Marvel's iconic and beloved creation Spider-Man could return home and join the ranks of this ever-growing franchise. But it always seemed like such a pipe- dream... Something that could never happen. After all, Sony owned the rights to the character, and had crafted a franchise including some very well- received and wildly successful films centered on the wall-crawler. Heck... still to this day, director Sam Raimi's "Spider-Man 2" is one of the finest comic-book to film adaptations ever released.

Then something magical happened. A deal was struck, and it was announced that Marvel and Sony agreed to work together to bring Spider-Man into the MCU. Fans were thrilled. Spirits ran high. And we eagerly awaited the return of one of our favorite characters. And after a brief introduction in last year's fantastic "Captain America: Civil War", we finally have the first stand-alone Spider-Man adventure in Marvel's universe- "Spider-Man: Homecoming." And it is a welcome and extremely successful work that emerges as one of Spidey's best films to date!

It's been several months since Peter Parker (Tom Holland) joined Tony Stark (Robert Downey Jr.) for his last adventure, and young Peter is starting to feel antsy and under-appreciated. He passes his time juggling schoolwork, stopping petty crimes and endlessly calling Stark's second-in- command Happy Hogan (Jon Favreau), begging for the next mission so that he can prove himself and become a proper "Avenger." But Peter soon finds himself drawn into a treacherous and life-threatening situation when he learns of the rise of a new supervillain- Adrian Toomes (Michael Keaton), a disgraced former salvage worker who had been driven out of business and has taken to using recovered alien technology from the "Battle of New York" to develop and sell advanced weaponry to criminals. And Peter will quickly learn that his adolescent desire to prove himself could very well spell his doom when Toomes sets his sights on eliminating the wall-crawler using an advanced weapons-system he developed that turns him into the dreaded "Vulture"...

Directed by Jon Watts, "Spider-Man: Homecoming" excels thanks to its absolutely wonderful cast and the phenomenal atmosphere it crafts, filled with humor, adventure and intrigue. Tom Holland showed a promising start in last year's "Civil War", but here he shows us that he is beyond a shadow of a doubt the absolute definitive on screen Spider-Man. He plays Peter as that delightful underdog dork that we know and love, while also giving Spider-Man that trademark comedic and energetic edge. Holland is destined for super-stardom. Michael Keaton is also just perfect as a troubled man who has been taken down a dark path into a life of crime. Like many of the great Spider-Man villains, you sympathize with Toomes while also loving to hate him for the terrible things he does, and Keaton is clearly having a great time playing such a villainous role. Supporting actor Jacob Batalon is a ton of fun as Peter's best friend Ned, who quickly learns Peter's secret and turns into an immediate fanboy who vows to help him in any way he can. Marisa Tomei and Zendaya are both very good in their respective roles as Peter's supportive Aunt May and offbeat classmate Michelle, and both get their moments to shine. And of course Robert Downey Jr. is a blast and a half as Tony Stark... pretty much as expected at this point.

The film is exceedingly well constructed and boasts a phenomenal tone and atmosphere that in a lot of ways hearkens back to classic high-school comedies of the past. It's no secret that John Hughes was a big influence on the film's many sequences set in Peter's school, and I actually found these to be some of the most effective scenes. It captures that magical, youthful energy you'd see in movies like "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" and "The Breakfast Club", yet still has a flavor all its own. I wasn't sure about seeing Peter back in High School yet again, but by far this movie does the most creatively with the concept. The handling of character and story is wisely done, with everything kept fast and loose, yet also with just enough breathing room to develop. It's never a dull film, but you also always know what's happening, which character is where in their emotional states and how the grand story is moving along. And to top it off, the action and effects are absolutely mind-bending to boot! With a good combination of both practical and digital effects and the imaginative minds at Marvel, Spider-Man has never looked so good!

In the end, it really comes down to one simple fact- "Spider-Man: Homecoming" might not necessarily be the best Spider-Man film. And it isn't quite flawless. It does have a few minor issues that pop up here and there and they do hold it just shy of getting a perfect score from me. But for the most part? It is a thrilling, enthralling, endlessly charming and wildly exciting ride and a grand return home for the character. Not only does it feature the best on screen Spidey yet, but it also boasts sharp writing, entertaining action set-pieces, witty humor, likable characters and a whole lotta heart. And honestly... there isn't much more I could ask for, and I am most certainly looking forward to the inevitable sequels and follow-ups. I give "Spider- Man: Homecoming" an excellent 9 out of 10.

title: There is no such thing as a perfect Spider-Man movie... but this is the closest we've got
review:
​'SPIDER-MAN: HOMECOMING' was directed by Jon Watts and stars Tom Holland, Michael Keaton and Jacob Batalon.​Thrilled by his experience with the Avengers, young Peter Parker returns home to live with his Aunt May. Under the watchful eye of mentor Tony Stark, Parker starts to embrace his newfound identity as Spider-Man. He also tries to return to his normal daily routine -- distracted by thoughts of proving himself to be more than just a friendly neighbourhood superhero. Peter must soon put his powers to the test when the evil Vulture emerges to threaten everything that he holds dear.

I don't think the day we see the definitive Spider-Man movie will ever come. But if this is the closest we'll get, I'm happy with that. Homecoming is probably the best Spider-Man movie and is the definition of fun. It does what Marvel does best but does it so that it doesn't feel like it was copying the other movies. It was funny, action packed and contains the best Spider-Man we've had. One of the best entries to the MCU.

Marvel's strong point has never been the plot and that is no different here. The plot is scarily loose and had an stupidly low amount of effort put into it. You could argue that the story is important but that statement is untrue. The story is the driving force of the movie and any film that neglects it has a special place in hell.

Please stay until the end of the credits of this movie. Don't skip them or you wont get the full effect of the scene. It is one of the best after credits sequences purely because it is merely supposed to be a little bit of fun, which also drives home the tone of the movie.

Tom Holland is fantastic in this movie. He is both my favourite Peter Parker and Spider-Man. Casting someone actually young as Spider-Man was a blessing after the 'special' age of Spider-Man-ing from Maguire and Garfield. Holland was consistently funny and made the movie very, very entertaining.

Bravo Michael Keaton. You retain your title as a god damn incredible actor. Your performance as Vulture was fantastic and, aside from one throwaway gag in the middle, you were frequently intimidating and scary. Vulture is easily my favourite MCU villain and that is mainly down to Keaton's brilliant performance. I can not commend the man enough. He stole the show for me in this movie. Well done, sir. Well done!

Jacob Batalon was good as the comic relief and served his purpose well. He never overstayed his welcome and he was consistently entertaining. Comic relief's can either be great or obnoxious, and Ned definitely leans to the former of the two. Laura Harrier was alright as Liz. Liz was just the girl, however. That is it. She was the girl the lead has a crush on and will save once or twice. She had no other purpose in the movie and I was very disappointed by it. As much as the Webb films have their issues(and they do), Gwen Stacey was an interesting character and actually contributed to the plot. Liz does not. And that is something I was very annoyed with in the film. I like Tony Revlori's take on Flash. I know many people will not but I personally found it to be a very entertaining and interesting take. Zendaya was fine as MJ but I would have liked a little more genuine development in her character, rather than a complete change in it. Jon Favreu was good as Happy Hogan. Nothing more needs to be said. I was also thrilled that this is a Spider-Man movie, not a collaboration between Spider-Man and Iron Man. They utilised Robert Downey Jr effectively in this movie and made the scenes he featured in mean something, and didn't make them feel like throwaways.

I love the way this movie was shot and edited. It was a very impressive looking movie and visually interesting. The special effects were a treat to behold. Guardians 2 probably has better effects but they managed to make a guy in a wing suit look realistic so props to them for that. The costume and set design was also really interesting and didn't feel lazy. Actual effort was put into it.

The action in this movie is top notch. Some may argue it is lacking until the last act(where this movies takes off for flight) but I disagree. More minor moments sprinkled throughout building to an actual climax is, in my opinion, better than having 1 huge battle during the middle and then having the two leads wrestle in the rain for five minutes *cough* John Wick *cough*. And then we have the climax. It is excellent. I loved it and, while I think there was a wasted opportunity involving the theme park, it was still very well handled.

Comedy is one Spider-Man's defining traits. That is what has set him apart from other superheroes. And that is one of the movie's defining traits. It is stupidly funny and entertaining. It is a fun movie and that is what it needed to be. You'll have fun watching this movie and, despite my hatred of Marvel plots, it is a thoroughly enjoyable ride from beginning to end. I highly recommend this movie to comic book fans. I'll rate this movie 9 PATIENCEs out of 10!

title: some good bits but underwhelming over all
review:
Spiderman Homecoming is about an unpopular teenage boy called Peter Parker who is secretly the superhero Spiderman. The only person who knows about his secret is Tony Stark who made his suit.

Spiderman is played by Tom Holland who plays the role of Spiderman really well. He was very believable and realistic and very funny at times. He was definitely the best part of the movie for me, i think he will be remembered as one of the best Spidermen. I also liked the fact it wasn't the normal Spiderman origin story that everyone already knows about. How his uncle got shot and that made him want to make a difference. That would just be boring. Instead they told a different story but it was still technically an origin story, the film is about Peter wanting to be the best superhero and Tony Stark stopping him and saying he's not ready. The main villain is The Vulture and is played by Michael Keaton who's good and compared to marvels other villains is better, but not anything all that great. There are parts were he's menacing but never all that scary.

Now i'll talk about the main negatives. To be honest I actually just thought that the script for Spiderman Homecoming was just a bit poor. There were some jokes that worked but there were also some that just fell completely flat at times. A lot of the good jokes came when Tom Holland was playing Peter Parker, but when he was Spiderman a lot of the quips he was saying felt more cringey then funny. Another problem i had with the film was that although Peter was well written and the vulture also had a good character, almost all the other character were completely uninteresting, especially his love interest who was really boring and also the bully Flash who was just really annoying.

Spiderman Homecoming had pros but I felt that the cons out shined them and I was pretty underwhelmed by the film and would say you should just go watch the Sam Raimi ones with Toby Maguire.

title: Spider-Man Homecoming Review: He's back and with lots of fun & entertainment, action packed!
review:
Movie: Spider-Man Homecoming (UA)

Rating: 4.5/5

I know you won't believe me, but I seriously don't watch Hollywood films. The only Hollywood films I've seen include STRAW DOGS (2011) and first three films of the SPIDER-MAN series. Spider-Man has been my childhood favourite since long. I always wanted to catch one of films on the big screen. And I got this opportunity a few weeks ago. I never imagined it could see it in 3D. This was my first experience and I seriously loved it! Plus, Tiger Shroff's Hindi dubbing for Spidey too added to the fun.

Synopsis wise, it might look like a simple Spidey flick but don't think that it's an ordinary one. The story and screenplay are both watertight and fully engaging. It doesn't have any such flaws you can dig out easily. Besides, who would like to find flaws when our superhero wants to entertain us?

Entertainment is present fully throughout the film. Those who've loved Spider-Man, should never afford to miss this film. Technically, this film is a masterpiece and there are no noticeable glitches at all. This film intends to entertain as well as deliver a good social message. What's that? Watch it soon to find out.

The action scenes of the film are a major plus and look even better in 3D. The background score of the film is excellent and elevates the viewing experience. The editing is perfect as there are no unnecessary or boring sequences. Each and every scene is a masterpiece.

Tom Holland as Spider-Man is very impressive. Robert Downey Jr. as Tony Stark, the Iron Man is excellent. Other actors too are excellent.

The film also has a good dose of humour, largely natural, and keeps us entertained. I was surprised to see how the director has also made the film suit to Indian audiences in an amazing way. The Hindi dubbing excellent. Kids and families can watch this film definitely.

Having said that, SPIDER-MAN HOMECOMING is a must see for any Spider-Man fan and also for those who want visually engaging, endless action-packed entertainment. And for the best experience, watch it in 3D, as it looks even better in that format. Highly recommended!

title: "Spider-Man: Homecoming": One-Sentence Review
review:
"Spider-Man: Homecoming": One-Sentence Review

Paying homage to John Hughes' 80s Brat Pack films, "Spider-Man: Homecoming" expertly juxtaposes the perils of high school drama against the backdrop of a well-constructed superhero movie.

10 out of 12 Tamales

For more one-sentence reviews, check out tamalemoviereviews.com

title: Spidey's Finally Come Home, and the Wait was Worth It!
review:
Thirteen years have now passed since the last truly great Spidey flick graced us with its presence in cinemas; Spider-Man 2 came out way back in 2004 (God, I feel old). And I was starting to believe we'd never see another good depiction of the web- slinger. Then, Marvel Studios signed a contract with the greedy ass-hats at Sony, and his movie rights were restored -- Spidey was finally back home.

Let me tell you: I never thought I would get to see Spider-Man (Tom Holland) humiliating low-life bike thieves and helping innocent old ladies cross the busy streets of Queens to the beats of "Blitzkrieg Bop" by Ramones, and it was glorious. Every bit of it worked. This fresh, light-hearted, John Hughes-esque take on everyone's favourite wall-crawler is exactly what we've needed, because we finally get to see him as he was in the comics: a nerdy, unpopular high-schooler -- just a kid.

Is this version of Peter Parker riding his skateboard in the halls of the school? Is he flaunting finger guns and air-humping in the streets of New York?? No, he's dealing with crushes, and parties, and dances -- all of which are, in the mind of a teenager, just as scary as having to battle it out with any winged super-villain. He also spends time building lego Death Stars and such with his pal, Ned (Jacob Batalon) -- who owns every second of his screen-time -- and, despite his advice from Tony Stark (RDJ), does not seem to want to "forget about the flying, vulture guy."

It's just not in Peter's nature to watch someone -- not unlike himself on a thematic level, by the way -- get away with so much bad, even when the reasoning is surprisingly sound (Michael Keaton's vulture is one of the better Marvel villains in recent memory). He carries with him this sense of child-like purity that we haven't seen before. Believe me: this charming innocence really comes into play near the climax of the film -- during a tremendously impactful tribute to a very special issue of the earlier comics. I might've even shed a tear or two.

I know that Spider-Man: Homecoming is already doing spectacularly well at the box- office, but I still encourage you to go and see it. Have fun with it. You haven't seen Spidey like this before, and he's well worth your time. It's great. Trust me.

title: Everything is GREAT!
review: I'm not a big marvel fan,but I'm going to say this movie is amazing. Strong cast(Aunt May is so sexy!)、wonderful storyboard and aspiring morality,no doubt the movie is highly recommended. But I think the personalities of spider-man is not that accurate. When it comes to Spider-man series,what came in to my mind was Tobey Maguire in 2002'spider-man movie,his performance is perfect.I don't think spider-man is a handsome guy or just virtually a nerd.

title: A Successful Fresh Start
review:
"Spider-Man: Homecoming" is a successful, fresh start to one of the most loved, Marvel Comics character. Playing a 15-year-old Peter Parker/Spidey is Tom Holland, who is perfect for the role, and better at it than any other actor who played the webslinger in previous movies and TV specials (yes, there were live-action, Spider-Man TV specials a long time ago). After coming home from his epic battle in Europe ("Captain America: Civil War"), Holland is back in Queens, NYC, itching for a new mission from his mentor, Tony Stark/Iron Man (played by Robert Downey Jr.). But his dream of another epic fight doesn't come, and Holland is forced to do street level superhero stuff while juggling the cruelties and confusion of High School.

Then one day, Holland comes upon a weapons deal that leads him to a gang of criminals who deal in modified, alien tech. A gang that is led by The Vulture. A gang that will test the teen-aged superhero in every way. With his pleas for assistance from Downey Jr. seemingly going unanswered, Holland takes it upon himself to stop The Vulture from stealing more alien tech that will kill many more lives. But the cost of saving lives may cost Holland his own.

My most memorable, movie moment of "Spider-Man: Homecoming" is the final scene of the movie. I won't spoil it, but I will say it was shocking and very funny.

Let me address a big problem many fans/moviegoers had with this movie: Spider-Man's lack of his "spider senses," which warn him of dangers. I do believe he does have his spidey senses; but it is done in very subtle way. In the comics and cartoons, Spidey says things like "My spider senses are tingling..." Well, we can't have that in the movie, because it'll just sound retarded. When Spidey is dodging bullets or items being thrown at him, we just have to assume part of him doing that is because of his spidey senses. And yes, I know Spider-Man gets hit quite often in this movie...that's not proof of his lack of spidey senses. In the comics and cartoons, Spider-Man takes hits also, despite having spider senses that warn him of immediate danger. He's not perfect, once in a while he gets hit. Also, remember that in this movie, Spider-Man is 15-years-old, and still adapting to his newly-found powers, powers that sometimes overwhelm his senses. His suit addresses that sensory overload, but not completely. So, bottom line, this isn't an issue for me. Moving on...

"Spider-Man: Homecoming" is a very good movie that I think will satisfy most fans of this character. Tom Holland once again kills it with his portrayal of a teen version of Spider-Man, as does Downey Jr. with his flawless take on Tony Stark. Add to this lots of huge, action sequences, numerous funny moments, an interesting villain, great special effects...it all adds up to a very memorable, Spider-Man movie.

I do have to mention a huge shenanigan though: a plane full of extremely valuable/dangerous items is flying solo, no guards inside, no automated Iron Man soldiers, no military escorts? It just relies on a stealth tech, and it has a "blind spot" that The Vulture takes advantage of? Get the hell out! But for this huge, glaring shenanigan, I would have given this movie an "A" grade. It doesn't ruin the movie, of course; but it does take quite a bit of the shine off.

Mannysmemorablemoviemoments

title: Another good Marvel movie
review:
Spider-Man: Homecoming might be the most light hearted movie so far in the Marvel Universe. It essentially begins right after Peter Parker has his fight in Captain America: Civil War. The opening is Peter filming his journey after being recruited by Tony Stark. Just a little backstory as to how he showed up in Civil War.

Back to real life, Peter struggles with the normality. He wants so badly to be back with the Avengers that he's missing out on his high school experience.

The villain in the movie is the Vulture played by Michael Keaton, who I really enjoyed in the role. There was a deeper meaning behind his motives which caught me off guard and I liked it.

It's a fun film and isn't as intense as most Marvel movies. Tom Holland is a good young actor and his charisma was perfect as the new Spider-Man. A solid 8/10

title: It's a Wonderful Day In the Neighborhood for Spidey!
review: I am going to keep this review short, sweet, and simple. This Spidey movie may be better than Spider-Man 2 in certain aspects. I really enjoyed both the action, and the acting. Tom Holland is great as both Peter Parker, and his alter-ego Spider-Man. You can really feel his anxiety, and empathize with him. Michael Keaton actually makes for a fantastic intimidating villain with his own moral code in this one. You both sympathize with, and despise the guy at the same time. I never thought I'd see the day where I actually would like Vulture. The rest of the supporting cast play their roles fairly well too; especially Peter's friend Ned Leeds. He is a funny side character with a few standout scenes of his own. There were a couple of scenes where I found myself chuckling. The action in this one is pretty stellar, and Spider- Man is exactly how he should be in this one. He is the wise cracking, swashbuckling teenage hero he was intended to be. The costume is better than any previous iteration in my opinion. This one made more sense in a lot of ways, and was more faithful to the comics. They even play an adaptation of his old cartoon theme! All in all, an amazing movie!

title: Se7en for the Comedy!!!
review: The Marvel movie we've all been waiting for this year. Our favourite spidey is back, and this time he's even more funnier. Tom Holland fits completely in the suit. Though we miss Tobey Maguire & Kirsten Dunst (not Andrew Garfield) but still Downey Jr. makes up for them. Sorry for those who were expecting hot Mary Jane. And BTW Marisa Tomei as Aunt May is icing on the cake. Looking for a good comedy this weekend then go for it...

title: Great movie but too many spoilers in the trailers and some weird castingchoices
review:
Let's start with saying: I liked this movie a lot. It's a fresh take on the Spiderman movies we've seen in the past and a clear part of the Marvel Cinematic Universe.

We've seen Tom Holland in Captain America: Civil War and he made quite a strong impression there as the somewhat clumsy, young and witty Spider-man. So my expectations for his stand-alone movie were quite high.

And they did deliver it well. It was a fun and exciting coming-of-age/high school movie with a a great villain in alien-arms-dealer Michael Keaton. And Robert Downey Jr./Tony Stark in a somewhat struggling father-figure role. And because we have a really young Peter Parker, we can also have a younger than usual aunt May, funny and vibrant Marisa Tomei.

So far so good. Some disasters Spidy has to prevent/fix are directly because his own doing. He jumps into situations without a second thought and deals with them on the spot. This brave and hyperactive Spidy fits well in the MCU and is bound to be a comic relief for a lot of coming movies.

So, the writing, camera-work, editing, production, directions and acting is great - why not a 10? Simply because the trailers (except for the home-video teasers) gave away too much of the movie. I new what was going to happen and that took away a lot of fun and excitement for me. I go to the cinema a lot, so it's hard not to look at the trailers. And it felt too politically correct in casting. Especially Flash was cast wrong. Tony Revolori did well for the part he got, but my Flash is a big mostly physical bully in the comics and the choice for a short snakelike mean character who is part of the decathlon team seemed off.

Apart from that I enjoyed the movie a lot 8/10

title: Does pretty much everything right
review: I'm not a big fan of Marvel films. I've liked a few of them, and none of them have been outright terrible, but they're mostly just average and nothing to write home about. I think Spiderman: Homecoming feels so fresh because it isn't concerned with the usual "save the world" plot that many of these films are. It's incredibly grounded and what it has going for it is a lot of relatable, actually funny humor centered around Peter Parker's life as a teenager. More than anything that is what the film gets right: the tone of high school. The action sequences in this are well done but none of them bog down the film's true heart. This is pretty much everything the film needed to be.

title: Very Very Funny
review:
Spider-man Man: Homecoming or Spider-man: back to home.

Peter Parker (Tom Holland) after being called by Tony Stark to his side in Captain America: Civil War, must deal life in high school and in his own house, and at the same time become little by little in an avenger.

Let's start with the actors. Tom Holland as Peter Parker/Spider-Man is a great success for the film. Holland has the character, personality, age, (not like the others...), and when I discovered that Holland was groin, causing it to explode, I did not expect it, his accent is almost perfect. Michael Keaton (Batman) as Adrian Tooms or the Vulture, is the best part of the movie. Before the premiere we had all the hope in this villain, and exceeded expectations. It is a great character, their reasons are comprendibles, until some (the audience) are characterized with the character. And the truth is that Zendaya was OK, not outstanding, but well, like Jacob Whole Battalion as Ned, very funny. And Aunt May that is one of my favorite parts of the movie, with all that is sexy on the streets, in the restaurant, until they tell Peter in the school. I liked the character of Robert Downey Jr. as Iron Man (obviously)

Thanks Sony for giving the rights, if not we would not have this movie. The sub machine gun of jokes, jokes, references in the film is impeccable, i think i saw 1 or 2 jokes out of place, but all (which were many) were very gracious and place each one of them. Marvel knows how to move these characters (for example Spider-Man) not as Sony does not know how to exploit to the maximum (The Amazing Spider-Man: The threat of electro)

Very funny 9/10

title: Just a blast to watch.
review:
I mean, it's an MCU film, so you can always count on the movie being fun, quippy and well made. This new Spider-Man film is no different, and that's certainly not a bad thing.

It's not a groundbreaking movie, and overall I didn't think it was as good as the first two Raimi films, nor last years Captain America: Civil War, which introduced Tom Holland's portrayal of Peter Parker, but I felt that it was a step above Spider-Man 3 (which is still good), and both of The Amazing Spider-Man films (which are far from good).

Tom Holland is as good in this as he was in Civil War, showing the teen awkwardness of Peter Parker and also the heroism of Spider-Man. I surprisingly enjoyed the villain, The Vulture, as played by Michael Keaton, who, in a surprise twist, is the father of Liz, Peter's love interest (I warned you about spoilers). Liz herself is okay, but about as forgettable as Rachel McAdams' character from Doctor Strange. Zendaya and Jacob Batalon both do well as friends of Peter, and provide good comic relief. Robert Downey Jr and Jon Favreau both feature as returning characters from previous Marvel movies, and do a good job, and surprisingly, Gwyneth Paltrow also reprises her role as Pepper Potts, which was neat to see.

The action scenes are good, but I still don't feel as if any Spider-Man films have lived up to the action from the Raimi films, particularly the third one which featured numerous great action scenes. Of course, the CGI was excellent, like in every MCU film.

Some problems I have are, as mentioned, the less than stellar fight scenes, and the bland love interest. I also felt as if this film featured more plot holes in conjunction with the rest of the MCU than normal, which was strange.

Overall though, it was really enjoyable and another fun entry into the ever expanding Marvel Cinematic Universe.

title: Its nice and well done
review:
After seeing this film I didn't come out saying that it was the greatest film ever or the best one in the MCU, but instead saying this a a very cool take and also a very different take on the Spider Man character. Marvel defiantly understands Spider Man and understands his history and who he is supposed to be and I really felt that hear. It was nice to watch a Spider Man movie where the main actor really does feel like a kid who is just trying to survive life. And that much alone I really enjoyed and had a lot of fun.

The Vulture played by Micheal Keaton is also a very good villain for Peter Parker to face. The guy is truly scary and truly threatening as well and that was something I really enjoyed about the film. With most MCU films the villains are pretty meh for the most part, so it was nice to see a villain who was scary and made your worry for the hero's life. That was a definite positive. Also the fact that the villain didn't hurt the rest of the movie was good to. Cause Guardians had a good villain too but sadly it hurt the rest of the movie.

I also really enjoyed the Zendaya's character. I thought she was really charming and really funny too. She was a great and very interesting character to me who I defiantly enjoyed when she popped up on screen. There is also a twist with her character that I won't spoil.

Overall while not one of my favorite movies in the MCU I still had a good time. I had a lot of fun with it and would defiantly recommend it.

title: Spider-Man, Spider-man, can MCU do it? Yes it Can!
review: I think they have finally got the character of Spider-man right. He's a great mix of the nerdy, uncool Peter Parker we went and the cocky, quipping Spider-Man. And while they do great with him and give him a good character arc, I think they failed for the most part with other characters. Zendaya's Michelle shows up here and there to say a quip and then disappears. Otherwise she's mainly thrown in as a set up for a future movie. Aunt May doesn't have much to do in this film besides be the "hot Aunt" that everyone hits on. Donald Glover is in the movie for 2 scenes and he also is mainly there as a potential set up for a future movie. The only other character that I felt was decently fleshed out was Adrian Toomes (Vulture). I think they gave him some good backstory for why he hated Iron Man/The Avengers so much. And there were several good fights between him and Spider-man where he had the upper hand. And there was a really great acted, tension filled moment between the two of them in a car. And that's all I say about that scene because I'm trying to keep this review as spoiler free as possible. I think he was one of the better villains. The other weird thing I want to point out, is the timeline doesn't make sense. When we are first introduced to Vulture, its right after the events of the first Avengers (which was like 2012 I believe) but then it cuts to an "8 years later screen. Which either means this takes places in like 2020. Or The Avengers was taking place in like 2009. However, later in the film Happy Hogan makes a reference to something he's been holding onto since 2008 (which is when the first Iron Man came out). So......very confusing. I know some people don't like the fact that Iron Man built Spider-man's suit, but I think it makes sense for this universe and it does provide for a really funny scene once he gets the "training wheels" off and doesn't know how to use it because Tony went overboard with all the options. There is also plenty of other funny moments in the film, one of my favourites had to do with Ferris Bueller. I'm not sure how would I rank it amongst the other MCU movies. There's so many at this point, and I feel like I would have to do a re-watch. But, between the other MCU movie that came out this year, I think I enjoyed GOTG 2 a little bit more.

title: Definitely better than Andrew Garfield.
review: Spiderman: Homecoming was a good movie, but I didn't think it was as much fun as the new Wonder Woman film that I recently watched. Although I'm more fond of Toby Maguire, I would say that Tom Holland is better that Andrew Garfield. I never like Garfield btw. His Spiderman suit also looked good in its cartoonish kind of way. Michael Keaton was a good choice for the Vulture. The Vulture suit was pretty cool and menacing. My only gripe about the Vulture is that he didn't have that much screen time. When the film starts, you get to see him for a couple minutes and about half an later, you get to seen him for another minute, etc. The part where Vulture finds out that Peter is Spiderman is when the action between Spiderman and Vulture actually starts. That's about an hour and a half into the movie. I was rather disappointed with Shocker. They only used him in a couple of brief scenes then quickly gets killed off. Then he quickly gets replaced with another one of Vulture's minions and they only used him for one brief scene. I was never that fond of Shocker, but it felt like a wasted opportunity to introduce him to the big screen. The one character I just did not like when Peter's classmate Michelle. She is the most unlikable character ever. Even more so than Flash Thompson. Every time you see her, she always makes some smart ass remark to Peter or his friend Ned. When you see her at Lizzie's party, she flips a bird at Peter when he first shows up. When Peter is in detention, she shows him a sketch she made of him being miserable with a cold look on her face. I the movie but I wouldn't call it outstanding. Out of all the movies that they made up till now. I would say homecoming is better than the Andrew Garfield movies, Spiderman 3, and underneath Spiderman and Spiderman 2.

title: GOOD But Not Great
review:
It Started All well, the beginning was in a new form not what every Spiderman movie has BUT as the movie went on it didn't fell like i was watching Spiderman . it seemed like another version of avengers

After when Peter Parker finds out that his enemy is Liz'S father, the whole movie takes a complete U-Turn One side is Peters Love OTHER side is his enemy i thought that this would be also a movie like BMVSSM which was 3 hrs long but then suddenly peter runs to kill LIZ'S father and then it turns out he saved him from dead , his funny Spiderman suit was great

Basically My point of saying is they stretched the movie and then rather than completing it they ended it, which was great disappointment .

It is a good Movie But Still In MY OPINION SPIDERMAN 2 WAS A BANGER

title: Spiderman for the modern age
review: I really didn't fancy going to see Spider-Man: Homecoming but with there being no football at the moment and my youngest pestering me to go , I succumbed . I haven't really been into Spider-Man since the cartoon TV show of the seventies and with all the changes of lead actors I wasn't holding out great hope but I was pleasantly surprised. Thrilled by his experience with the Avengers, Peter Parker returns home under the watchful eye of his new mentor Tony Stark . Parker tries to fall back into his normal daily routine—distracted by thoughts of proving himself to be more than just your friendly neighbourhood Spider-Man—but when the Vulture (Michael Keaton) emerges as a new villain, he finds that there is a massive conflict between his Spidey life and his private life. Tom Holland is excellent as the new Spider-Man. He's playing a 15 year old Peter Parker and that will definitely appeal to the kids. In fact the whole film feels like it's aimed at the younger market. There is less death and destruction than a usual Avengers movie ( and this IS an Avengers movie) and more references to what teenagers are into. Some of the special affects are amazing especially one scene where Spider-Man climbs up the Washington Monument ( great in 3D) also a scene on a ferry. It could do with half an hour being shaved off of it but I think that of most Marvel films . Not Bad at all.

title: *SPOILER REVIEW* The morning after viewing the film.
review:
Overall, I really did enjoy the film, getting it right off of my chest – The orchestrated Spider-Man theme at the beginning was epic! I had a huge smile on my face as it took me back to my childhood of watching the cartoon and got me in great mood before the film got started.

This was definitely the best incarnation of Peter Parker that we have seen to date – I had high hopes for him after seeing him in Civil War anyway and Tom Holland did not disappoint. Peter was appropriately aged and was portrayed as being nerdy, yet clever.

I really liked Holland's portrayal of Spider-Man, the fact that you could see him failing at certain webslings was good; this made it more believable, since if you tried doing it in real life, you'd almost certainly bump into things and injure yourself. – It also made sense for that to be happening as the film was going for a 'coming of age story' for Spider-Man, rather than an origin story. Additionally, I really enjoyed the scene where he had nothing to latch his web onto and had to run; this is something I used to query a lot as a child, so it was great to see it acknowledged in a humorous way.

The Vulture was a great portrayal, much better than the cartoon series in my opinion. Michael Keaton was a great villain when he was just being Liz's dad – very calm and calculating. I also really liked his origin story at the beginning of the film and how it tied into The Avengers.

All of the Avengers stuff was cool; Iron Man didn't overshadow Spidey, which I was pleased with. The new Avengers building looked great and helped to build up the hype for Infinity War.

Moving onto the weaker aspects of the film: Firstly, I wasn't too keen on Peter's best friend, Ned. Although he was moderately entertaining at times and it was good to see Peter have someone to nerd out with about Star Wars, I personally thought he was over-used and often slowed the film down. Furthermore, the pacing of the film was quite slow at times – the scene when Spidey was locked in the storage room with the bomb was particularly slow; I remember briefly drifting off and checking my watch at that point.

I didn't like the fact that Vulture wasn't named as 'Vulture' in the film – people who don't know Spider-Man might not even know he was supposed to be called that. Maybe it's just me, but I enjoy referring to heroes and villains by their proper names and not their human names. – If you know what I mean?

No Spider sense! Or at least it didn't feel like he had it. I noticed this because Spidey got caught off guard a few times in the film – for instance, when Vulture swooped down and picked him up; surely he should have sensed this?! However, he might still be developing this as he's learning throughout the film so it's kind of forgivable – Maybe he'll have his Spider-Senses in the next one now that he's developed more as a hero. However, I'm not too keen on the fact that Spider-Man is now overly reliant on technology. He feels a bit too much like Iron Man rather than a radioactive teenager with spider powers. – This is something that the Toby Maguire films, love them or hate them, portrayed the best in my opinion.

However, the biggest problem for me was the second half of the film, when Spidey had no suit at the end. I understand that the point is to develop him as a hero in his own right and to teach him a moral lesson, but I felt that too much time was invested into it and I was really disappointed that the final battle wasn't showing Spider-Man using the powers he was supposedly learning throughout his various training modes with Karen.

Furthermore, I hate that Tony Stark is allowed to say: "If you're nothing without the suit, then you shouldn't have it." – Literally 'Pot/Kettle/Black'! – Iron man without his suit is just rich. Even Captain America had the whole, "Put on the suit" fiasco with him in the first Avengers film so he really has no right to say this.

In conclusion, Spider-Man Homecoming was a good film; I enjoyed a lot of it. However, I felt that the first half of the film, watching Peter learning his suit powers and trying them out was a much more enjoyable portion and by this point I had great expectations to see these abilities come into play – this made it far more disappointing to see them all scrapped towards the end. I felt that instead of showing Peter as a novice at the start and seeing him develop his powers and use them at the end, they went backwards and showed him have powers at the start and took them away. Therefore, in my opinion, this wasn't a perfect Spider-Man film, nor was it my favourite Marvel movie. I was happy with it, but I still feel that there was room for improvement.

title: Felt more like a Marvel movie then a SONY product.
review:
SPIDERMAN HOMECOMING -Spiderman is back at home , and that's Marvel. Although it's wrong to say BACK because in movies he has never been at Marvel before.

At the start let me rank it among the other Spiderman movies . And it's just my personal ranking. Its third best for me after the best Spiderman 2 (which most of the people think is actually the best one) and Amazing Spiderman 1 (this one people may disagree). So you can say inclusion of Marvel gave mix results bending towards the positive side.

But I do think this movie felt more like a Marvel movie then the earlier Spiderman movies by SONY. Mostly because of the two reasons. 1st being the obvious one , inclusion of Iron Man and his Iron Manish Jokes. And the movie is full of them. Even when Iron Man is not their in the screen. And 2nd - casting of Tom Holland (for which credit goes to Kevin - the head of Disney and Russo Bros - the director of Cap America 2 and 3. And it's easy to say for me that Holland is the best Spiderman and fit perfectly with the tone of MCU. He looks exactly like a 15 year old school boy. And has a nice sense of humour.

This fact that Spidey is back in school gave the makers a chance to make the movie light hearted , full of jokes , lowering the stakes (I mean the world is not under any danger this time).

But then again the movie lacks Seriousness , Tension , Emotions , etc. No shock value. No edge of the seat scenes , no heart warming scenes like what I got in Wonder Woman. What I mean is that I had the usual problem I always have with the Marvel Movies. So that's just about my personal taste.

Also to add , about which I am not much sure but Spidey in this movie has been shown as pretty much incapable. Apart from the Climax fight , every time Iron Man has to come to rescue him . This may make hard core Spiderman fans a little disappointed. Just may be. Didn't bothered me. Because I am not that die hard fan.

The movie is too much crowded with characters. Not everyone get a meaty role having the running time of 133min. The best example is ZENDEYA , being just another student , having no real purpose , cracking dry jokes. May be she will get a little more important role in the sequel.

Being in High School , Peter was very immature . Apart from fighting street thugs he was tackling usual high school problems - bullying , failure to express his love to the senior girl , not having many friends and yes the most usual one BALANCING HIS PERSONAL LIFE WITH Professional , I MEAN SUPERHERO LIFE.

One of the great thing about this movie (which I think should be given credit to but I also think most of the audience will not be able to catch the fact ) is that how close the ambition of both the hero and the villain were in the movie. Both has been demoralized by Tony Stark and Both wants to prove something to Tony and to society. Yet both have a different way to do it.

Michal Keaton as vulture was good. For a change we got a nice villain in a Marvel movie. Again it's owned by SONY so it just half qualify as Marvel movie. Vulture is good , not great. He had a clear motive. He wants to do business. Trying to earn a standard lively-hood. Still I didn't find him enough menacing.

Action scenes were good. Not very unique creatively , but good. The broken ship pulling scene was very familiar to Toby Macquarie's train stopping scene from Spiderman 2 , but didn't reached the height of the tension which Toby's scene had done. No other complains from action. If only the climax scene had been done in the daylight instead of Night , would have been so much better.

The first half was very good. Extremely funny. But when the movie jumped to 2nd half the stakes should have been gone higher. Which never happens. Also whatever serious or sad scenes were there director was not able to make them gripping which is a shock because I loved the direction of John Watts in COP CAR.

There were some minor visual effects which looked more like Video Game scenes , but mostly visuals were great.

3d being always nice in Spiderman movies was good here too.

Robert Dn Junior had just the right amount of role neither overshadowing Spidey(if only we ignore the fact that he rescues him all the time) nor dissatisfying his own fans having a small role.

I love Marisa Tomei. She is extremely beautiful even at the age of 52 years. She is a perfect Aunt May. Would have been great if we had got some more emotional scenes of her with Peter.

Small thing to add. SHOCKER has always been one of my favorite villain from Spiderman Cartoon. And I always wanted him to be shown in movies. And I got it. Yes as a sidekick of vulture , not a very powerful villain but at least get a chance on big screen.

7.3/10 by ANuP APu KuMaR

title: Fun energetic feel good movie, that gives us the Spider-Man we have been craving!
review: Spider-Man Homecoming tells the coming of age tale Peter Parker as he struggles to balance school, family, and being a superhero and that's what it should be. This film brings Spider-Man back to his charm as what made Spidey so relatable was that he was not a larger than life superhero but one of us. Tom Holland does a phenomenal job portraying Peter Parker/ Spider-Man with his youthful charm, and infectious charisma, as does everybody else. One stand out in particular being Michael Keaton as the Vulture. Having significantly more depth than your standard MCU villain Michael Keaton delivers a joyfully over the top performance with a surprising amount of depth. However although this film does have a lot to love about there are still many flaws that may make it a disappointment for some viewers, one big one being that the film has no weight to it. Everything from the emotion to the action feels without any stakes and frankly just underwhelming. Where as every Spider-Man movie from this point had pretty exceptional action scenes (including The Amazing Spider-Man 2) this one included several jump cuts and no impact. There are also a few minor issues with the film, without getting into spoiler territory there was one scene in particular that was very clearly an advertisement for an Audi. Overall although I would still say Sam Raimi's Spider-Man 1 and 2 are still better this is undeniably a very fun enjoyable summer flick. As far as Marvel movies go I'd say this one's pretty great. And I'm giving this one a 7 or 8/10.

title: Spider-Man: Homecoming Film Review
review:
The new Marvel superhero film Spider-Man: Homecoming starring Tom Holland, Robert Downey Jr., Michael Keaton, Marisa Tomei.

In Spider-Man: Homecoming a young Peter Parker / Spider-Man (English actor Tom Holland - The Lost City Of Z, In The Heart Of The Sea), who made his sensational debut in Captain America: Civil War, begins to navigate his newfound identity as the web-slinging super hero in Spider-Man: Homecoming. Thrilled by his experience with the Avengers, Peter returns home, where he lives with his Aunt May (American actress Marisa Tomei - The Wrestler, The Big Short), under the watchful eye of his new mentor Tony Stark / Iron Man (American actor Robert Downey, Jr. - Iron Man films, Avengers films). Peter tries to fall back into his normal daily routine – distracted by thoughts of proving himself to be more than just your friendly neighbourhood Spider-Man – but when the Vulture / Adrian Toomes (American actor Michael Keaton - Batman films, Birdman) emerges as a new villain, everything that Peter holds most important will be threatened.

Amongst the other actors / actresses in Spider-Man: Homecoming includes American actor Jon Favreau (Iron Man films, The Wolf Of Wall Street) as Happy Hogan, American actress Gwyneth Paltrow (Iron Man films, Shakespeare In Love) as Pepper Potts, American actress Zendaya (US TV Series K.C. Undercover and Shake It Up!) as Michelle, American actor Donald Glover (The Martian, Magic Mike XXL) as Aaron Davis, Jacob Batalon (North Woods) as Ned Peter Parker's friend from school, Laura Harrier (TV Series One Life To Live, 4th Man Out) as Liz, American actor Tony Revolori (The Grand Budapest Hotel, The 5th Wave) as Flash, American actor Bokeem Woodbine (Ray, The Rock) as Herman Schultz, American actress Tyne Daly (US TV Series Cagney & Lacey, The Enforcer) as Anne Marie Hoag, Abraham Attah (Beasts Of No Nation) as Abe, American actor Hannibal Buress (Bad Neighbours films, The Nice Guys) as Coach Wilson, American actor Kenneth Choi (Captain America: The First Avenger, The Wolf Of Wall Street) as Principal Morita, Selenis Leyva (US TV Series Orange Is The New Black, Living With The Dead) as Ms. Warren, Angourie Rice (The Nice Guys, Jasper Jones) as Betty, American actor Martin Starr (Superbad, Knocked Up) as Mr. Harrington, Haiti actress Garcelle Beauvais (White House Down, Flight) as Doris Toomes Adrian Toomes' wife, American actor Michael Chernus (Men In Black 3, The Bourne Legacy) as Phineas Mason / The Tinkerer, Canadian actor Michael Mando (US TV Series Better Call Saul which is the Breaking Bad Spin-Off TV Series, TV Series Orphan Black) as Mac Gargan, American actor Logan Marshall-Green (Prometheus, The Great Raid) as Jackson Brice, American actress Jennifer Connelly (Hulk, Noah and who is married to English actor Paul Bettany in real life) as Karen, American actor Gary Weeks (The Nice Guys, Project Almanac) as Agent Foster, Christopher Berry (Django Unchained, 12 Years A Slave) as Randy, Jorge Lendeborg Jr. (The Land, Brigsby Bear) as Jason, Tunde Adebimpe (Rachel Got Married, Jump Tomorrow) as Mr. Cobbwell, Chinese actress Tiffany Espensen (Repo Men, Earth To Echo) as Cindy, American actress Isabella Amara (The Boss, Wilson) as Sally, Michael Barbieri (Little Men) as Charles, J.J. Totah (Other People, Time Toys) as Seymour, American actor Hemky Madera (The Lost City, Joshua Tree) as Mr. Delmar, American Marvel Creator Stan Lee who always appears in Marvel films played a normal guy called Gary and American actor Chris Evans (Captain America films, Avengers films) as Captain America / Steve Rogers.

Filming locations in Spider-Man: Homecoming includes cities, places, US States like The Big Apple New York City, Washington D.C. the capital of America, The City Of Angels Los Angeles, California, Anaheim, California, Atlanta, Georgia, Fayetteville, Georgia, Berlin the capital of Germany in Europe.

Overall Spider-Man: Homecoming is a good Marvel superhero film filled with superheroes, villains, action, shooting, violence, fast and furious paced action, thrills and spills, on the edge of your seat stuff, the battle between good and evil, some near misses and close shaves, explosions, things getting wrecked, destroyed, blown up, good shots of the tall high rise skyscrapers of New York, helicopters, chases on foot and in vehicles, FBI Agents, police, school, friendship, loyalty, team work, togetherness, aircrafts, people working underground, fights, battles, catchy music and many other things throughout the film.

So I will give Spider-Man: Homecoming an overall rating of 3 out of 5 stars and Spider-Man: Homecoming is worth seeing if you like any of the previous Spider-Man films or any of the other Marvel films or any other superhero films out there whether it's Marvel or DC.

So if you get the chance to see Spider-Man: Homecoming in the cinema then you should go and see it sooner than later but in my opinion Spider-Man: Homecoming is good don't get me wrong but it's not as good or better than the previous Spider-Man films with Tobey Maguire and Andrew Garfield and for me Tobey Maguire is the best actor to play Spider-Man in films and my favourite Spider-Man is Spider-Man starring Tobey Maguire as Spider-Man from 2002 but at the same time Tom Holland does play Spider-Man pretty well in Spider-Man: Homecoming and you can pick and choose which Spider-Man film is the best and which actor plays Spider-Man best in films.

review:

It was really a great movie with lot of amazing visuals.Tom Holland did an amazing job as Spidey and Peter Parker in the movie, pretty sure that this guy did not disappoint anyone. i am 100 percent sure whoever purchase ticket for this movie will not regret coming out....
